name: Banana Leaf Necklace
description:
This product is made from dried leaves of the banana trees that grow in abundance in the tropical regions of Central Africa. They are cut into strips and rolled into a variety of beautiful perlés (beads). The familiar red mud is used to make clay beads in a small handcrafted kiln. The result is a treasured work of art and love.

The artisans are part of a collaboration project at Project Hope and Charité (PHC) in the Central African Republic. The group is comprised of widows who are caring for orphans and orphans who have completed their basic education in the PHC program.
The goal of this Fair Trade project is to teach the skills to create beautiful and high quality jewelry using natural materials. It provides
widows and orphans with the opportunity to make an income in a safe environment from readily available materials in a country
where jobs are scarce. It also encourages skill development, creativity, hard work, and excellence.

WPCAR2

name: Recycled Popcan Earrings
description:
These whimsical earrings add color, style and a clear statement to any collection. Look good while doing good. These earrings are made by students in Nicaragua in partnership with Nica Hope. Nica HOPE is a new outreach of Fabretto Children's Foundation to the communities in and around the Managua City trash dump, offering long-term solutions to entrenched poverty through education and practical skills training. Nica HOPE provides increased opportunities for youth and adults from the communities that currently depend on the trash for income and survival.

Made in Nicaragua

name: Simple Adjustable Acai Seed Bracelets
description:
These adjustable bracelets merge simplicity and spirituality - honor the plants of the rainforest in these sustainably harvested seeds and show off your savvy! Variety of naturally dyed seed colors available.
Ecological handcrafts from Bolivia honor the life of the rainforest through sustainable harvesting of rainforest seeds. Seeds include cesibieto de la palmera, acai, and jachirilla. Acai berries are known for their healthful properties, but the seed makes up 90% of the berry. By creating exquisitely simple adornments with these seeds, indigenous families support valuation of the forest and its precious resources. As rainforest resources are exploited by outside companies, projects like this small business help keep resources and decisions about those resources in the hands of those who have lived in its canopy for centuries. The purchase of this piece supports indigenous families’ microenterprises, the health of the forest and the spirit of its people.

Made in Bolivia

WPI2

name: Laos Silk Scarf
description:
These handcrafted silk scarves use natural dyes and a simple, but revolutionary handloom to spin the silk. Mulberries and More, a WFTO Fair Trade organization in Laos, has revived the art of silk weaving, natural dying and mulberry production in Laos. Each scarf comes with a tag describing the berries, flowers and other natural ingredients in each dye.
Mulberries and More (Lao Sericulture), in partnership with over 200 village families, specializes in the production of naturally-dyed, handmade Lao silk. 
Handmade silk production is a labour-intensive task that requires a high level of expertise and diligence from the artisan. Each step - from the growing of mulberry saplings, the feeding of worms, the reeling of silk, to the weaving of cloth - requires time and skill. Your purchase helps to keep this traditional Lao art alive by providing women and men with training, resources and a sustainable livelihood.

Sold by assortment only.

Made in Laos
